intro: Duosperma fanshawei, commonly known as the "Chinese ghost flower," is a striking member of the Acanthaceae family. It is native to China and is characterized by its unique, showy inflorescences that resemble ghostly faces, hence its common name. The plant features opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a velvety texture and produces clusters of tubular, two-lipped flowers in shades of violet and pink. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
